Understate: The claim understates the fact that not all registered sex offenders are on the national registry and therefore not all of them are barred from driving for ride-hailing companies.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide specific evidence or data to back up the assertion that sex offenders can drive for Uber or Lyft.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that all sex offenders pose an unacceptable risk to citizens, without considering individual circumstances or rehabilitation efforts.
Exist alternative explanation: There could be alternative explanations for why some sex offenders are allowed to drive for ride-hailing companies, such as the consideration of their risk level or the effectiveness of rehabilitation programs.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Level 2 and Level 3 sex offenders, who are on the national registry, are barred from driving for ride-hailing companies.
